  +
The '''Egyptian parliamentary elections of 2010''' was held in [[Egypt]] on 28 November 2010<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/10/201010201482298875.html Egypt elections set for November 28 - Middle East - Al Jazeera English<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="Electoral calendar for 2010">[http://www.mherrera.org/elections.htm Electoral calendar for 2010]</ref><ref name="IFES Election Guide">[http://www.electionguide.org/country.php?ID=65 IFES Election Guide]</ref> while the second round of the elections was held on 5 December 2010.<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2010/10/101020_elections_egypt.shtml Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election - 20 October 2010 - BBC.co.uk<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="Egypt opposition split over election boycott">[http://arabinform.org/news/egypt_opposition_split_over_election_boycott/2010-09-26-407 Egypt opposition split over election boycott - 26 September 2010 - Arabinform.org<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The '''Egyptian parliamentary elections of 2010''' was held in [[Egypt]] on 28 November 2010<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/10/201010201482298875.html Egypt elections set for November 28 - Middle East - Al Jazeera English<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="Electoral calendar for 2010">[http://www.mherrera.org/elections.htm Electoral calendar for 2010]</ref><ref name="IFES Election Guide">[http://www.electionguide.org/country.php?ID=65 IFES Election Guide]</ref> while the second round of the elections was held on 5 December 2010.<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/arabic/middleeast/2010/10/101020_elections_egypt.shtml Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election - 20 October 2010 - BBC.co.uk<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name="Egypt opposition split over election boycott">[http://arabinform.org/news/egypt_opposition_split_over_election_boycott/2010-09-26-407 Egypt opposition split over election boycott - 26 September 2010 - Arabinform.org<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The election was scheduled in two-stages to form the Ninth Assembly since the adoption of the [[Constitution of Egypt|1971 Constitution]]. 444 ordinary seats were being contested<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> with 64 additional seats reserved for women,<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> while the president appoints 10 members,<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> making a total of 518 seats.<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" />
The election was scheduled in two-stages to form the Ninth Assembly since the adoption of the [[Constitution of Egypt|1971 Constitution]]. 444 ordinary seats were being contested<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> with 64 additional seats reserved for women,<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> while the president appoints 10 members,<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" /> making a total of 518 seats.<ref name="Mubarak sets a date for parliamentary election" />

==Background==
 
This election follows the Muslim Brotherhood completing the five-year parliamentary term in which it held on as the largest-ever minority bloc.<ref name="aljazmb"/>
